I. 

INVESTMENT PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
equity investment in Darby Asia Mezzanine Fund II, Limited Partnership (the Fund) of up to $20 
million, or 25% of the Fund’s capital, whichever is less. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will 
not be the largest investor in the Fund. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: BACKGROUND, CHALLENGES, AND OPPORTUNITES  

[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELTED] 

A. 

Role of Mezzanine Finance and Its Demand in Asia 

1. 

Role of Mezzanine Financing in the Economy 

2. 
As  with  other  forms  of  financing,  mezzanine  satisfies  a  specific  risk-return  demand  for 
investors  and  investee  companies.  It  represents  a  financing  layer  that  typically  sits  between 
equity  and  senior  debt  in  the  capital  structure  of  a  company  or  project  in  terms  of  seniority 
(Figure  1),  and  is  a  long-term  source  of  generally  unsecured  but  amortizing  risk  capital. 
Mezzanine financing has fixed income-style performance characteristics, in the form of current 
interest  income.  In  addition,  it  typically  includes  equity  upside  features,  such  as  warrants, 
convertibility  rights,  or  profit  participation  rights.  Mezzanine  debt  usually  is  structured  as  a 
subordinated  loan  with  a  bullet  repayment  after  7–10  years.  Because  the  principal  under 
mezzanine  financing  largely  is  repaid  as  a  bullet,  investee  companies  benefit  from  access  to 
additional free cash flows for organic growth.1  

 

Figure 1: Capital Structure of 
Financial Instruments by Seniority 

 

Senior Debt 
 
 
 
 
Subordinated Debt  
 
 
 
Subordinated Debt 
 
with warrants or 
 
conversion rights 
 
 
 
Redeemable 
Preferred Equity 
 
 
 
 
 
Equity  
 
 
 

 

Mezzanine  
Finance

        Source: Private Equity International. 2004.  
        The Guide to Private Equity Fund Investment Due Diligence. London.  

                                                 
1 Private Equity International. 2004. The Guide to Private Equity Fund Investment Due Diligence. London.  

 Mezzanine  has  advantages  in  some  situations,  precisely  because  it  is  between  pure 
3. 
debt and equity. Growth companies that need expansion capital often lack a broad base of fixed 
assets  or  receivables  that  banks  require  to  lend  senior  debt.  Such  companies  also  might  not 
have a history of positive cash flow that is long enough to persuade a senior lender to provide 
cash flow-based financing. In these situations, mezzanine has the advantage of supporting the 
balance sheet by providing an external source of financing, without diluting the equity stakes of 
the  owners  of  the  company.  In  many  cases,  particularly  in  emerging  markets,  mid-market 
owners have a strong aversion to equity dilution, making mezzanine their only viable financing 
alternative.2
 
4. 
Additionally,  mezzanine  financing  often  plays  a  significant  role  in  leveraged  buyouts 
(LBO). The presence of mezzanine increases leverage in a transaction, enhancing the expected 
returns  of  the  equity  sponsor  as  the  investee  company  pays  down  the  mezzanine  and  senior 
debt. This allows for transactions of size and complexity that might not exist without this asset 
class. Further, mezzanine can be used as a replacement for senior debt during recapitalization 
or  refinancing.  In  such  situations,  it  also  provides  more  flexibility  for  ongoing  expansion  and 
lower leverage. 
 
5. 
Finally, mezzanine financing is particularly well-suited for longer-term investments, such 
as  those  in  infrastructure,  because of  the  current  income  provided  by  this  asset  class.  Due  to 
the long life of infrastructure projects and investments, investors often prefer to provide capital 
that involves fixed or variable current interest repayments, as opposed to more standard private 
equity  arrangements  that  are  much  riskier  due  to  their  heavy  emphasis  on  back-end  financial 
returns.  Moreover,  banks  often  are  hesitant  to  supply  long-term  risk  capital  to  mid-market 
infrastructure companies—an opportunity that mezzanine finance providers can seize. 
 

2. 

Mezzanine Finance in Developed Economies 

Mezzanine  financing  began  in  the  1950s  when  insurance  companies  in  the  United 
6. 
States  (US),  in  search  of  a  specific  risk-return  profile,  began  granting  equity-linked  notes  to 
private,  mid-market  companies.  European  banks  and  private  equity  firms  soon  caught  on  to 
mezzanine,  and  the  use  of  this  mode  of  financing  flourished  throughout  in  the  1970s.  In  the 
1980s,  as  independent  mezzanine  funds  began  to  form  in  the  US,  a  dichotomy  suddenly 
emerged in  the high-yield bond markets: mezzanine began to be used mainly for transactions 
below  $75  million–$100  million,  while  larger  transactions  were  financed  with  high-yield  bonds. 
The introduction of LBOs, as well as the increasing importance of private equity over the past 
few decades, also has spurred investment in mezzanine (footnote 1). 
 
7. 
In  the  US,  mezzanine  is  now  a  traditional  source  of  allocations  to  alternative  assets  of 
institutional  investors.  In  Europe,  the  volume  of  mezzanine  financing  has  increased,  as  it  has 
spread geographically from more traditional markets (e.g. the United Kingdom and, to a lesser 
extent, France and the Benelux countries) to other continental European countries. Today, the 
US has more than 120 independent mezzanine specialists, while Europe has about 30. These 
lend  to  mid-market  companies  looking  for  a  source  of  expansion  capital,  or  deploy  capital  as 
part  of  the  funding  packages  of  LBOs.  Coupled  with  mezzanine  provided  by  banks,  this 
phenomenon  translates  into  $10  billion  of  mezzanine  financing  in  the  US  and  €4  billion  in 
Europe in 2003. Expansion capital accounts for about half of all mezzanine financing in the US 
and about 15% in Europe. By contrast, mezzanine in Asia has a short history, with only 4% of 
private equity financing structured as mezzanine capital. 

                                                 
2 Private Equity International. 2004. The Guide to Private Equity Fund Investment Due Diligence. London.  

 2 

 

  

 

3

3. 

Economic Development and Demand for Mezzanine in Asia 

8. 
In 2005, developing countries in Asia benefited from strong global growth, which resulted 
in  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  rising  8.6%.  Growth  in  2006  is  expected  to  rise  similarly  at 
8.2%. 3  Over  the  long  term,  Asian  economies  are  projected  to  grow,  supported  by  favorable 
demographics, as well as increasing economic, trade, and political and social liberalization. The 
World Bank projects real annual GDP per capita growth for East Asia and the Pacific to be 5.3% 
during  2006–2015,  more  than  double  that  of  global  growth,  which  is  forecast  to  be  2.1%. 4 
However, as strong as this growth has been and is projected to be, Asia’s nascent private equity 
industry is still focusing mainly on large transactions, leaving a gap in mid-market equity finance. 
This  creates  enormous  potential  for  the  issuance  of  mezzanine  capital  in  the  region  for  the 
following reasons: 
 

(i) 

 
(ii) 

 
(iii) 

Asian midsize deals remain under-penetrated. Despite the publicity generated 
in the press regarding private equity activities in emerging markets, much of the 
recent  Asian  private  equity  fundraising  and  investing  remains  focused on  larger 
buyouts  and  restructurings  in  Australia  and  Japan.  While  the  activity  in  2005 
shifted significantly away from buyouts and toward growth/expansion capital—of 
the  $15  billion  invested  in  Asia  in  2005,  larger  buyouts  accounted  for  less  than 
50% of the transaction aggregate (versus 70% in 2004)—the size of the average 
deal  in  Asia  ballooned  by  31%  to  $63  million.5  This  leaves  significant  room  for 
midsized transactions. 

Companies  with  enterprise  valuations  less  than  $200  million  tend  to  lack 
public sources of financing. For a successful initial public offering (IPO), Asian 
companies  typically  need  to  reach  an  equity  valuation  of  $200  million–$500 
million.  Despite  improvements  in  the  banking  system  and  debt  capital  markets, 
lending and equity investing continues to focus on larger companies. 

Institutionally intermediated mergers and acquisitions in Asia tend to focus 
on  large  deals.  Less  than  8%  of  the  US  dollar  amount  of  mergers  and 
acquisitions traced by Bloomberg during 1999–2004 were within the range of $10 
million–$50  million.  The  diminished  role  of  financial  intermediaries  for  this  size 
creates a better environment for deal sourcing, pricing, and negotiation.  

 
9. 
While  mezzanine  financing  is  prevalent  in  the  US  and  certain  Western  European 
countries, this asset class remains relatively new in ADB’s developing member countries (DMC). 
Even  worldwide,  only  a  few  mezzanine  fund  managers  are  dedicated  to  emerging  markets.  
One  of  the  principle  reasons  for  the  undersupply  of  Asian  mezzanine  capital  and  expansion 
capital is that domestic financial institutions focus on collateral- and asset-based lending. Thus, 
of the $17.6 billion of private equity investments in Asia in 2004, only 4% (less than $1 billion) 
were  in  the  form  of  mezzanine  capital.6  For  most  midsized  acquisitions  in  Asia,  the  acquirer 
generally  must  fund  the  transaction  internally.  Banks  in  Asia  remain  reluctant  to  provide 
acquisition funding to even their strongest clients. This reluctance, coupled with the tendency of 
company owners in DMCs to eschew equity dilution, makes mezzanine financing an attractive 
alternative to traditional bank or equity financing. For investors who seek alternatives to equity 

                                                 
3  International Monetary Fund. 2006. World Economic Outlook. Washington, DC.  
4   World Bank. 2006. Global Economic Prospects. Washington, D.C. 
5  Asia Private Equity Review. 2006. Year-End Review 2005. Hong Kong, China. 
6  PricewaterhouseCoopers. 2005. Global Private Equity 2005. London. 

 

  4 

 

investments  in  emerging  and  transition  economies,  mezzanine  financing  offers  an  attractive 
risk-return  profile.  It  provides  current  income  and  often  allows  for  upside  participation  through 
“equity kickers,” such as warrants, without exposing the lender to the same downside risks as 
are traditional equity investors.  
 

4. 

Infrastructure Financing and Resultant Demand for Mezzanine 

10. 
In  the  infrastructure  sector,  many  DMC  economies  are  substantially  underinvested, 
relative to more developed economies, in sectors such as electric power, transportation, water, 
and telecommunications infrastructure facilities. In March 2005, the first joint study by ADB, the 
Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation,  and  the  World  Bank  estimated  that  developing 
countries in East Asia need to spend more than $1 trillion over the following 5 years on roads, 
water,  communications,  power,  and  other  infrastructure  to  cope  with  rapidly  expanding 
economies,  increasing  populations,  and  growing  demands  of  the  private  sector.  The  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) alone is expected to require 80% of the total investment.7 Foreign and 
private sources are expected to provide a substantial portion of these requirements. Because of 
the  need  for  additional  infrastructure,  among  other  motivations,  many  countries  in  Asia  have 
adopted  policies  that  seek  to  attract  private  sector  entities  to  invest  in  and  manage  such 
facilities. 
 
Given the substantial expenditures in ADB’s DMCs going forward, infrastructure assets 
11. 
offer a highly attractive investment opportunity for investors who seek to increase their exposure 
to  Asia.    Not  only  do  infrastructure  investments  provide  good  returns,  they  also  have  a  low 
correlation with other assets classes, allowing asset managers and investors to reduce overall 
portfolio  risk  and  build  more  efficient  portfolios.  Moreover,  mezzanine  financing  is  particularly 
well-suited  for  funding  infrastructure  investments,  because  of  the  current  income  it  provides 
(versus  more  popular  equity  investments  in  Asia  private  equity,  which  investors  would  find 
difficult  to  finance  due  to  the  long  life  and  uncertainty  of  infrastructure  investments).  Fund 
managers  operating  in  Asia  recognize  these  benefits,  as  evidenced  when  Darby  Overseas 
Investments  Ltd.  (the  Fund  Manager  or  Darby)  assumed  control  of  the  $246  million  Asia 
Infrastructure  Mezzanine  Capital  Fund  (AIMCF)  in  March  2002.  Under  the  Fund  Manager’s 
stewardship, AIMCF has completed its investment phase, negotiated restructurings of its most 
challenging investments, and is on track to achieve a positive return. Further capitalizing on the 
opportunities  that  infrastructure  investments  offer  in  Asia,  the  Fund  Manager  closed  a  $610 
million  private  equity  infrastructure  fund  in  the  Republic  of  Korea  (Darby  Korea  Emerging 
Infrastructure Fund) in July 2006. 
 
12. 
Finally, the market for financing investment in infrastructure in the public and the private 
sectors  through  public–private  partnership  (PPP)  structures  is  growing  in  developing  Asia. 
Increasing constraints on government budgets are driving this market expansion, which is being 
facilitated  by  a  growing  acceptance  of  private  sector  involvement  in  public  infrastructure, 
services, and utilities. This growth is expected to continue and expand geographically, with PPP 
structures increasingly supplementing and augmenting the infrastructure investment capacity of 
governments. 
 
 
 
 
 

                                                 
7  ADB, Japan Bank for International Cooperation, and World Bank. 2005. East Asia needs $1 trillion for infrastructure 

over next five years. Tokyo, Manila, Washington, D.C. 

  

5

B. 
         [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELTED] 

Challenges and Opportunities 

13. 
Asia’s  growth  and  integration  into  the  world  economy  creates  highly  desirable 
investment  opportunities,  and  justifies  a  continued  role  for  ADB  as  an  investor  in  the  private 
equity markets of its DMCs. Asia’s integration into the global supply chain is inevitable, as the 
region  continues  to  produce  everything  from  raw  materials  to  high  value-added  technological 
goods  and  services.  Asia’s  share  of  trade  increased  from  14%  in  1990  to  21%  in  2004.  By 
comparison,  the  US  share  remained  steady  at  13%,  while  Western  Europe’s  share  increased 
only  marginally  from  36%  to  39%  despite  the  formation  of  the  European  Union.8  With  Asia’s 
low-cost and increasingly skilled labor force, improving infrastructure, and ongoing liberalization 
of  trade  flows,  Asia’s  global  integration  is  likely  to  continue  to  create  opportunities to  invest  in 
entrepreneurial  companies  that  contribute  to  sustainable  economic  growth,  improved  living 
standards, and poverty reduction. 
 
14. 
However,  the  current  challenge  that  ADB’s  DMCs  face  is  that  entrepreneurial,  mid-
market  companies  and  infrastructure  companies  severely  lack  viable  financing  alternatives. 
Asian private equity, for example, is notably under-penetrated relative to the rest of the world. 
Asia accounted for only 18% of the estimated $96 billion of global private equity investment in 
2004.  Excluding  Australia  and  Japan,  Asia  accounted  for  less  than  10%.  Asian  private  equity 
investment as a percentage of GDP is less than half that of North America and Europe (0.2% 
compared to 0.5% in North America and 0.4% in Europe). The main reason cited for the current 
tentativeness  is  a  shortage  of  credible  fund  managers,  and  the  lack  of  a  track  record  for 
emerging markets private equity as an industry. Other key reasons include the perception that 
the risk-return trade-off is better in more developed markets, and that quoted equities offer more 
liquid and safer exposure to emerging markets.9
 
15. 
The  growing  interest  in  Asian  emerging  markets  private  equity  is  creating  unique 
opportunities for a fund manager with regional experience and a track record in ADB’s DMCs to 
help  deepen  the  liquidity  and  attractiveness  of  the  financial  markets  by  promoting  mezzanine 
financing.  An  investment  in  the  proposed  Fund  would  be  an  excellent  opportunity  to 
institutionalize  and  formalize  mezzanine  financing  and  middle  market  private  equity  financing, 
thereby positively influencing the enabling environment for private sector development. Further, 
the  Fund  would  be  required  to  collect  information  on  regulatory  issues  that  its  portfolio 
companies  encounter,  which  would  be  reported  to  ADB’s  regional  departments  to  assist  the 
formulation of a supportive regulatory framework.  
 
16. 
Evaluation  studies  show  that  multilateral  development  banks  have  the  opportunity  to 
achieve a high development impact in the context of an underserved middle market by fostering 
investments  in  entrepreneurial  companies,  and  by  catalyzing  the  growth  of  a  nascent  private 
equity  industry.  The  International  Finance  Corporation  (IFC)  recognizes  the  relationship 
between private equity and development impact, and the catalytic effect of fund investments. In 
2003,  the  IFC  had  roughly  $1  billion  of  capital committed  to  private  equity  funds  globally,  with 
40% in Asia.10 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) has stimulated 
and  catalyzed  the  private  equity  industry  in  Eastern  Europe.  EBRD,  the  largest  private  equity 
investor  in  central  and  Eastern  Europe,  has  supported  many  private  equity  companies  in  the 
region,  where  managers  are  setting  up  their  fourth  and  fifth  funds  as  the  market  matures. 

                                                 
8  World Trade Organization database, October 2004. 
9   Coller Capital. 2005/06. Global Private Equity Barometer (Winter): 12. 
10  Barger, Teresa. 2003. Sustainable Growth and Development through Private Equity Funds. Washington, DC: IFC. 

 

 EBRD’s investments in private equity funds are an example of a multilateral development bank 
successfully  acting  as  a  catalyst. 11  ADB’s  Operations  Evaluation  Department  did  an  impact 
evaluation  study  of  ADB’s  investment  funds  in  2002.12    It  concluded  that  private  equity  funds 
achieved “major development impacts” in five areas: (i) mobilizing significant financial resources 
for  infrastructure  development,  direct  investments  in  industrial  enterprises,  and  portfolio 
investments; (ii) supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) and new entrepreneurs; 
(iii)  supporting  technology  development;  (iv)  developing  capital  markets;  and  (v)  generating 
employment.  
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED FUND 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELTED] 

A. 

Objectives and Description  

17. 
characteristics:  

 

Fund Objective.  The Fund’s mezzanine investments are expected to have the following 

Combination of fixed-income style performance characteristics (including current 
yield from coupons) with equity upside prospects.  

Downside protection of principal through debt covenants. 

Built-in  exit  through  amortization  of  the  underlying  loan  principal  to  address  the 
challenges  that  exits  from  equity  investments  present  in  emerging  economies, 
given  the  more  limited  opportunities  for  middle  market  companies  to  tap  into 
public equity markets. 

(i) 

 
(ii) 
  
(iii) 

 
(iv) 

Portfolio  of  loans  structured  to  have  cash  flow  characteristics  that  are  relatively 
predictable  and  stable,  and  consequently  allow  for  the  use  of  leverage  in  the 
Fund’s capital structure, with the objective of improving returns to investors. 

 
18. 
Focus  on  Middle  Market  Companies.  The  Fund  will  focus  on  middle  market 
companies with  successful  management  track  records  and established,  stable  cash  flows  that 
require  long-term  risk  capital,  typically  for  expansion,  acquisition,  buyout,  capital  restructuring, 
or debt refinancing. The Fund Manager expects that the majority of its investments will be used 
for expansion capital.  
 
19. 
The  Fund  will  invest  in  mezzanine  opportunities  within  Asia,  primarily  in  Peoples 
Republic  of  China,  India,  Indonesia,  Republic  of  Korea,13  Malaysia,  Philippines,  and  Thailand. 
The  Fund  will  pursue  investments  in  a  range  of  sectors  that  fall  into  two  broad  categories: 
infrastructure, and commerce and industry.  
 
20. 
Sector Focus. The Fund will target to invest approximately 50% of its investments in the 
infrastructure sector, and is legally obligated to invest at least 40% the Fund’s committed capital 
(including  senior  debt)  in  the  infrastructure  sector.  The  infrastructure  sector  includes  services 
that  have  been  privatized,  or  are  provided  under  contractual  arrangements  that  involve  a

documentation will include the necessary opt-out clauses to ensure that ADB funds are not invested in non-DMCs 
beyond the limit of 15%. 

 6 

 

 7

 

(i) 

 
(ii) 

 
(iii) 

partnership  between  the  private  and  public  sectors.  Within  the  infrastructure  sector,  the  Fund 
plans to target:  
 

Transportation.  Toll  roads,  bridges  and  tunnels,  cargo  terminals,  rail  freight 
transport operations, private urban and regional transport, and regional airports. 

Energy. Generation and distribution of power, oil, gas and heat; and renewable 
energy, such as wind energy. 

Telecommunication.  Fixed  line  telephony  networks  and  infrastructure,  and 
mobile data networks. 

 
(iv)  Waste  management.  Municipal  waste  collection,  treatment,  and  disposal, 
industrial  waste 
incineration  and  waste-to-energy  projects;  and 

including 
collection, treatment, and disposal. 

 
(v)  Water  and  wastewater.  Bulk  water 

transmission;  water 

treatment  and 

distribution; and wastewater collection and treatment. 

 
21. 
In  the  commercial  and  industrial  sector,  the  Fund  will  seek  investment  opportunities  in 
privately  owned  smaller  and  mid-sized  companies  that  operate  in  a  broad  range  of  industries. 
The  Fund  will  diversify  the  sources  of  finance  available  for  entrepreneurial  companies  by 
inclusion of mezzanine finance. Supporting these fast growing entrepreneurial companies has a 
high impact on economic development because these companies innovate, combine productive 
resources in new ways and create jobs. Once successfully accomplished, the implementation of 
a  new  production  process  may  also  yield  social  returns  above  financial  returns  because  it 
demonstrates to other companies that a process is feasible in a particular environment.  
 
B. 

Fund Manager  

[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELTED] 

22. 
Darby  is  a  global  emerging  markets  investment  firm  that  manages  private  equity  and 
mezzanine funds for institutional investors, multilateral agencies, and high-net-worth individuals. 
Nicholas  F.  Brady,  the  former  US  Treasury  Secretary  who  established  the  firm  in  1994, 
continues to serve as chairman. Richard Frank, chief executive officer of Darby, joined the firm 
in  1997  after  a  distinguished  career  as  a  World  Bank  managing  director  and  as  IFC  chief 
financial officer. In October of 2003, Franklin Templeton Investments, with $492 billion in assets 
under management, acquired Darby as its private equity and mezzanine finance arm.  
 
23. 
Darby  is  a  leading  provider  of  mezzanine  capital  in  emerging  markets,  with  more  than 
$450  million  invested  in  mezzanine  transactions  in  Latin  America  and  Asia.  It  has  been  a 
pioneer in introducing this form of finance to these markets. 
  

IV. 

INVESTMENT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 

A. 

Environmental and Social Safeguard Policies 

24. 
ADB’s  investment  in  the  Fund  is  classified  as  category  FI  under  ADB’s  Environment 
Policy.14  The Fund  Manager  has  experience  with  adhering  to  ADB’s  social  and  environmental 

                                                 
14  ADB. 2002. Environment Policy. Manila. 

 

 safeguard polices through its existing fund. The Fund Manager is developing an environmental 
policy and environmental management system (EMS) for the proposed Fund in cooperation with 
ADB.  Several  of  the  Fund  Managers’  investment  professionals  will  attend  ADB-sponsored 
training  to  increase  their  capacity  in  environmental  and  social  management.  Two  of  the  Fund 
Manager’s staff are assigned to environmental and social management.  
 
25. 
ADB’s  investment  in  the  Fund  is  classified  as  category  B/C  under  ADB’s  involuntary 
resettlement policy.15 No involuntary resettlement is foreseen in relation to any investments by 
the Fund. The Fund will adopt a resettlement framework that defines the policies, procedures, 
roles,  and  responsibilities  of  the  Fund  for  screening  and  management  of  involuntary 
resettlement by portfolio companies. 
 
ADB’s  investment  in  the  Fund  is  classified  as  category  C  under  ADB’s  indigenous 
26. 
peoples policy.16 No investments by the Fund are expected to impact indigenous peoples. The 
Fund Manager is required to screen and monitor portfolio companies to ensure their compliance 
with ADB’s indigenous peoples policy. The Fund will not make investments that impinge on the 
lands  owned,  or  claimed  under  adjudication,  by  indigenous  peoples,  without  full  documented 
consent of such peoples. 
   
B. 

Anticorruption, and Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism 

ADB  advised  the  Fund  Manager  of  its  policies  on  anticorruption, 17  and  combating  of 
27. 
money  laundering  and  the  financing  of  terrorism. 18  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good 
governance,  accountability,  and  transparency,  ADB  will  require  the  Fund  Manager  to  institute, 
maintain, and comply with internal procedures and controls following international best practice 
standards for preventing corruption, money laundering, or the financing of terrorism. The Fund 
Manager will be required to covenant with ADB to refrain from engaging in such activities. The 
investment  documentation  between  ADB  and  the  Fund  will  allow  ADB  to  investigate  any 
violation or potential violation of these undertakings. Through its due diligence, ADB is satisfied 
that the Fund Manager has put in place proper procedures to ensure that its portfolio companies 
are not engaged in corrupt activities or the financing of terrorism.  
 
C. 

Investment Limitations and Waiver 

28. 
The proposed investment is within ADB's country and equity exposure limits for private 
sector operations. However, it would exceed the industry exposure limit for capital markets and 
investment  funds,  which  is  set  at  15%  of  the  private  sector  portfolio.  The  capital  market  and 
investment funds industry accounts for 17.78% of ADB’s private sector portfolio. Following this 
investment,  it  would  increase  to  18.48%.  If  an  additional  $10  million  investment  in  Siam 
Investment Fund III, which will be presented to the Board in the next month, were included, the 
private  sector  portfolio  of  capital  market  and  investment  funds  would  represent  18.76%.  After 
considering this breach of the industry exposure limit, ADB’s Risk Management Unit supports a 
waiver  of  this  limit  by  Management  for  this  proposed  investment.  Management  has  agreed  to 
grant such a waiver.19 The Risk Management Unit is preparing a policy to reclassify the industry 
sectors  and  revise  the  limits  to  better  reflect  ADB’s  strategic  foci.  The  capital  markets  and 

                                                 
15  ADB. 1995. Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide to Good Practice. Manila (Appendix 1). 
16  ADB. 1998. The Bank’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples. Manila. 
17  ADB. 1998. Anticorruption. Manila. 
18  ADB. 2003. Enhancing the Asian Development Bank’s Role in Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of 

Terrorism. Manila. 

19  The exposure limits are set out in ADB Operations Manual, Section D10/BP, paras. 15–22. Manila. 

 8 

 

  

9

investment  funds  industry  comprises  mainly  private  equity  funds.  However,  most  equity  funds 
invest in many different industries and companies. Hence, ADB’s exposure is to the underlying 
industries  invested  in  by  each  fund,  not  to  the  generic  industry  of  capital  markets  and 
investment funds. The new industry sectors and limits will reflect this. 
 

V. 

ASSURANCES 

29. 
Following  the  approval  of  the  proposed  investment  by  ADB’s  Board  of  Directors,  ADB 
will  enter  into  suitable  investment  documentation  for  its  investment  of  up  to  the  lesser  of  $20 
million  or  25%  of  the  Fund’s  total equity  capital,  and  will  ensure  that  such  documentation  and 
other  principal  agreements  relating  to  the  Fund  will  be  on  terms  and  conditions  acceptable  to 
ADB and incorporate all relevant ADB policies. 

 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

30. 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  investment  in  Darby  Asia  Mezzanine  Fund  II  would 
comply  with  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the 
investment  of  up  to  the  lesser  of  $20  million  or  25%  of  the  total  equity  capital  of  Darby  Asia 
Mezzanine Fund II from ADB’s ordinary capital resources.  
 

 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 

 
 
 
 
17 October 2006

Concept 

Impact 

Performance Measures (Qualitative and/or Quantitative) 

Business Performance (Fund) 

• Financial objectives 

• Overall profitability of the Fund 

Economic Sustainability (Fund and Subprojects) 

• Efficient allocation of 
finance and/or provision of 
financial services to 
economically viable 
enterprises  

• Subproject economic performance 

• Stronger local entrepreneurship 

• Gross internal rate of return (database)a 
• Net internal rate of return (database) 

  

  

• Annual net profit of subproject  (must be growing in aggregate) (database) 
• Annual revenue of subproject  (must be growing in aggregate) (database) 

• Number of entrepreneurial projects receiving finance from the Fund (at least 5) 
(database) 
• Number of returning entrepreneurs and skilled workers from industrialized 
countries receiving finance and transferring skills (database) 

• Additional direct 
contributions of subprojects 
to the local economy 
 

• Contribution to government revenues 

• Contribution to widening the access to 
finance of SMEs 

• Additional debt raised by subprojects as a result of the mezzanine investments 
(at least 40 million) (database) 

• Provision of value-added services, 
enhancing the viability of companies 

• Number of enterprises advised (database) 
• Quality of advice in financial planning, expansion strategies, human resource 
development, accounting standards, corporate governance, and management 
training (PCR) 
 
 
• Increased amount of taxes paid by subprojects (database) 

• Employment generated 

• Number of jobs created by subprojects (database) 
• Quality of jobs created by subprojects, e.g., technical jobs (PCR) 

• Adoption of new technologies and 
production processes 

•  Positive externalities of the subprojects in 
the targeted sectors, such as additional 
handling volumes in ports, and passengers 
and cargo transported through airports 

• Increased investment in new technologies and/or in improvement of production 
processes by subprojects (PCR) 
• Number of subprojects implementing successful new technology (at least 50% 
of non-infrastructure subprojects) (PCR) 
• Actual capacity utilization of infrastructure companies once operations have 
started (must be increasing on aggregate) (PCR)

Impact

and financial market

sector of a developing member country (at least $150 million raised in

closing) 
 
• Growth in mezzanine finance in DMC’s financial sector (PCR)  
• Increased access to long-term finance (PCR) 

DMC = developing member country, PCR = project completion report, SME = small and medium-sized enterprise. 
a Performance measures followed by “database” will be monitored regularly in the framework of the Private Sector Operations Department’s database for funds. 
Performance measures followed by “PCR” will be measured at the PCR stage. 
b Growth in financial services in the domestic market will be measured at the economy level, not at the Fund level. 
Source: Asian Development Bank, Private Sector Operations Department.
